entry.et: Middle English kichene, from Old English cycene, from Late Latin coquina, from Latin coquere to cook cook

def.dt: :a place (as a room) with cooking facilities
:the personnel that prepares, cooks, and serves food
:an informal group of advisers to one in a position of power (as the head of a government)
:a cupboard with drawers and shelves for use in a kitchen
:a garden in which plants (as vegetables or herbs) for use in the kitchen are cultivated
:a mound marking the site of a primitive human habitation
:portraying or emphasizing the squalid aspects of modern life the kitchen–sink realism of contemporary British drama Current Biography
:being or made up of a hodgepodge of disparate elements or ingredients
:an establishment dispensing minimum dietary essentials (as soup and bread) to the needy
:a small building or shed that is usually adjacent to a house and is used as a kitchen in warm weather
